case_name: Oil and Natural Gas Commission v. Workmen

anchor.surface_text: Shri Bhandare, has submitted that this Court should not interfere with the conclusions of the Tribunal under Art. 136 of the Constitution as those conclusions are based on appreciation of evidence. However erroneous they may be, according to Shri Bhandare, it is not the practice of this Court to interfere with such conclusions. In our view, the Tribunal has not only made some contradictory observations about the practice prevailing in the other projects of the Oil Natural Gas Commission but has also misread the statement of Shri Hasan (M.W. 1). It has indeed wrongly interfered with the appellants decision in fixing the hours of work which was fully within its competence, and was not open to any valid objection. The conclusions of the Tribunal are, therefore, tainted with serious infirmity justifying re-appraisal of the evidence by this Court for coming to its own independent conclusion on such reappraisal.

concepts.interpretation: Court can interfere with Tribunal's conclusions under Art. 136 if tainted with serious infirmity, such as misreading evidence or wrongly interfering with management's competence, allowing re-appraisal of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen claimed that working hours of the administrative staff should have continued to be 6 1/2 hours per day and complained that fixation of 8 hours per day with effect from June, 1965 was violative of s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act hereinafter called the Act . It was further complained that the fixation of 8 hours per day was not justified from the point of view of convenience and was also at variance with the practice uniformly prevailing in other administrative offices of the workshops of the Oil Natural Gas Commission.

concepts.interpretation: Workmen's claim that change to 8 hours violated s.9A as it altered condition of service.

anchor.surface_text: On this reasoning S. 9A of the Act was held inapplicable to the case of the workmen at Baroda. The Tribunal next dealt with the contention that the change in the hours of work was not justified from the point of view of convenience and that the workmen being transferable all over the country and the pay scales being similar, hours of work in the Baroda workshop should not have been changed from 6 1/2 hours, including half an hour rest interval to 9 hours, including rest interval for one hour.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal held s.9A inapplicable as no condition of service fixed working hours at 6.5 hours per day; prior 6.5 hours was temporary due to construction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, on the facts and circumstances of this it cannot be said that 6 1/2 working hours a day was a term of service, for the simple reason that it was only during a period of the first six months, when the factory was being constructed at the site of the workshop that, due to shortage of accommodation, the administrative office was, as an interim arrangement, temporarily located in tents at a place about 2 k.m. away, that the staff in this office was not required to work for more than 6 1/2 hours per day.

concepts.interpretation: Court agrees s.9A not violated as 6.5 hours was not a term or condition of service; it was temporary interim arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: It was successfully contended by the workmen that though under the Factories Act the workmen may be asked to work for 48 hours a week or 8 hours a day, it does not necessarily follow that the clerical staff should also be made to work 8 hours a day when they had been working for only 6 1/2 hours a day from December 1964 to June 1965.

concepts.interpretation: Factories Act permits 48 hours/week or 8 hours/day for workmen, but tribunal considered it does not automatically apply to clerical staff.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is merit in the learned Attorney Generals submission. The management must, in our opinion, have full power and discretion in fixing the working hours of the administrative staff within the limits prescribed by the statute. When the change in the working hours is covered by s. 9A read with the First Schedule of the Act, compliance with the said section would undoubtedly be necessary for its sustenance.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General drew our attention to the decision in May Bekar Ltd. v. Their Workmen for the proposition that it is not open to the Industrial Tribunal to reduce the working hours either directly or indirectly where the employer was following the working hours prescribed by a statutory provision.

concepts.interpretation: Industrial Tribunal cannot reduce working hours fixed by employer in compliance with statute.

concepts.unlisted_label: Limits on Industrial Adjudication re Working Hours
concepts.unlisted_description: Tribunal cannot interfere with statutory-compliant working hours or fix to enable overtime earnings.

issues.text: Whether the demand of the workmen that the Oil Natural Gas Commission, Baroda should stop the extra hours of work which is being taken from the office administrative staff in workshop and fix their working hours on the lines of those of the office staff of the Commission is justified ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the demand of the workmen that the Oil Natural Gas Commission, Baroda should stop the extra hours of work which is being taken from the office administrative staff in workshop and fix their working hours on the lines of those of the office staff of the

issues.text: Whether the demand that the Commission should pay compensation to the administrative staff for the extra hours of work taken from them from June, 1965, at the overtime rate or pay factory allowance at the rate of 20 per cent of the pay to the office administrative staff who have been asked to work for 8 hours from June 1965 is justified? If so, to what reliefs are the workmen entitled ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the demand that the Commission should pay companypensation to the administrative staff for the extra hours of work taken from them from June, 1965, at the overtime rate or pay Factory allowance at the rate of 20 per cent of the pay to the office administrative staff, who have been asked to work for 8 hours from June, 1965 is justified? If so, to what reliefs are the workmen entitled ?

issues.text: Was there a valid and binding settlement between the parties on 20th January, 1968 as alleged ? If so, is the Reference beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal ?

anchor.surface_text: Was there a valid and binding settlement between the parties on 20th January, 1968 as alleged ? If so, is the Reference beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal ?

issues.text: Are the demands of the staff working in Purchase, P D and Accounts sections and Stores Department covered by the present Reference and beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal ?

anchor.surface_text: Are the demands of the staff working in Purchase, P D and Accounts sections and Stores Department covered by the present Reference and beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal ?

issues.text: Whether the fixation of 8 hours per day with effect from June, 1965 was violative of s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act?

anchor.surface_text: The workmen claimed that working hours of the administrative staff should have continued to be 6 1/2 hours per day and complained that fixation of 8 hours per day with effect from June, 1965 was violative of s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act hereinafter called the Act . It was further complained that the fixation of 8 hours per day was not justified from the point of view of convenience and was also at variance with the practice uniformly prevailing in other administrative offices of the workshops of the Oil Natural Gas Commission.

issues.text: Whether the management has full power and discretion in fixing the working hours of the administrative staff within the limits prescribed by the statute?

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is merit in the learned Attorney Generals submission. The management must, in our opinion, have full power and discretion in fixing the working hours of the administrative staff within the limits prescribed by the statute. When the change in the working hours is covered by s. 9A read with the First Schedule of the Act, compliance with the said section would undoubtedly be necessary for its sustenance.

issues.text: Whether this Court should interfere with the conclusions of the Tribunal under Art. 136 of the Constitution as those conclusions are based on appreciation of evidence?

anchor.surface_text: Shri Bhandare, has submitted that this Court should not interfere with the conclusions of the Tribunal under Art. 136 of the Constitution as those conclusions are based on appreciation of evidence. However erroneous they may be, according to Shri Bhandare, it is not the practice of this Court to interfere with such conclusions. In our view, the Tribunal has not only made some contradictory observations about the practice prevailing in the other projects of the Oil Natural Gas Commission but has also misread the statement of Shri Hasan (M.W. 1). It has indeed wrongly interfered with the appellants decision in fixing the hours of work which was fully within its competence, and was not open to any valid objection. The conclusions of the Tribunal are, therefore, tainted with serious infirmity justifying re-appraisal of the evidence by this Court for coming to its own independent conclusion on such reappraisal.

issues.text: Whether 6 1/2 working hours a day was a term of service of the administrative staff?

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, on the facts and circumstances of this it cannot be said that 6 1/2 working hours a day was a term of service, for the simple reason that it was only during a period of the first six months, when the factory was being constructed at the site of the workshop that, due to shortage of accommodation, the administrative office was, as an interim arrangement, temporarily located in tents at a place about 2 k.m. away, that the staff in this office was not required to work for more than 6 1/2 hours per day.

holdings.text: Once it is found that 8 hours a day has been properly fixed for work in the administrative office there can be no question of payment of any compensation

anchor.surface_text: Once it is found that 8 hours a day has been properly fixed for work in the administrative office there can be no question of payment of any compensation, for working for 8 hours a day in the past.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No extra hours if 8 hours properly fixed; no overtime or allowance due.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has not only made some contradictory observations about the practice prevailing in the other projects of the Oil Natural Gas Commission but has also misread the statement of Shri Hasan (M.W. 1). anchor.surface_text: In our view, the Tribunal has not only made some contradictory observations about the practice prevailing in the other projects of the Oil Natural Gas Commission but has also misread the statement of Shri Hasan (M.W. 1). It has indeed wrongly interfered with the appellants decision in fixing the hours of work which was fully within its competence, and was not open to any valid objection. The conclusions of the Tribunal are, therefore, tainted with serious infirmity justifying re-appraisal of the evidence by this Court for coming to its own independent conclusion on such reappraisal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal errors: contradictory findings, misread evidence, improper interference with management; serious infirmity justifies SC re-appraisal under Art.136.

holdings.text: this appeal succeeds and allowing the same we set aside the award reducing the working hours from 8 to 6 1/2 hours per day in the Baroda Central Offices and also set aside the order granting compensation at 10 of the salary

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal succeeds and allowing the same we set aside the award reducing the working hours from 8 to 6 1/2 hours per day in the Baroda Central Offices and also set aside the order granting compensation at 10 of the salary. The appellant will of course pay the costs of the respondent in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative errors by Tribunal warrant reversal; restore 8 hours and deny compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, on the facts and circumstances of this it cannot be said that 6 1/2 working hours a day was a term of service, for the simple reason that it was only during a period of the first six months, when the factory was being constructed at the site of the workshop that, due to shortage of accommodation, the administrative office was, as an interim arrangement, temporarily located in tents at a place about 2 k.m. away, that the staff in this office was not required to work for more than 6 1/2 hours per day.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is merit in the learned Attorney Generals submission. The management must, in our opinion, have full power and discretion in fixing the working hours of the administrative staff within the limits prescribed by the statute. When the change in the working hours is covered by s. 9A read with the First Schedule of the Act, compliance with the said section would undoubtedly be necessary for its sustenance.
he Act, companypliance with the said section would undoubtedly be necessary for its sustenance. In the present case, as already observed, s. 9A is num

anchor.surface_text: The office at Baroda being the controlling office its requirements and exigencies of work are such that fixing of 8 hours work a day is, in our opinion, fully justified, and the Tribunal was wrong in reducing its working hours to 6 1/2 hours a day.

The result, therefore, is that this appeal succeeds and allowing the same we set aside the award reducing the working hours from 8 to 6 1/2 hours per day in the Baroda Central Offices and also set aside the order granting companypensation at 10 of

edges.explanation: Holding h5 'no question of payment of any compensation' addresses issue i2 demand for compensation for extra hours

anchor.surface_text: Once it is found that 8 hours a day has been properly fixed for work in the administrative office there can be no question of payment of any compensation, for working for 8 hours a day in the past.

The result, therefore, is that this appeal succeeds and allowing the same we set aside the award reducing the working hours from 8 to 6 1/2 hours per day in the Baroda Central Offices and also set aside the order granting companypensation at 10 of

anchor.surface_text: ted and the administrative staff attached to it shifted to its own building at the factory site, that the management apparently on an overal

edges.explanation: Holding h6 identifies specific infirmities in Tribunal (contradictory observations, misreading), addressing whether to interfere under Art. 136 as per i7.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the Tribunal has not only made some contradictory observations about the practice prevailing in the other projects of the Oil Natural Gas Commission but has also misread the statement of Shri Hasan (M.W. 1). It has indeed wrongly interfered with the appellants decision in fixing the hours of work which was fully within its competence, and was not open to any valid objection. The conclusions of the Tribunal are, therefore, tainted with serious infirmity justifying re-appraisal of the evidence by this Court for coming to its own independent conclusion on such reappraisal.

The result, therefore, is that this appeal succeeds and allowing the same we set aside the award reducing the working hours from 8 to 6 1/2 hours per day in the Baroda Central Offices and also set aside the order granting companypensation at 10 of

edges.explanation: Holding h7 setting aside award reducing hours addresses issue i1 on stopping extra hours

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal succeeds and allowing the same we set aside the award reducing the working hours from 8 to 6 1/2 hours per day in the Baroda Central Offices and also set aside the order granting compensation at 10 of the salary. The appellant will of course pay the costs of the respondent in this Court.
